In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

You can use the built-in `replace` function in Julia to replace spaces with underscores. Here's a simple function that will do this:

```julia
function clean_column(col)
    return lowercase(strip(col)) |> replace(r"[- ]", "_")
end
```

This function `clean_column` first strips any leading or trailing whitespaces from the column name (`col`) using `strip`. It then converts all characters to lowercase using `lowercase`. Finally, it replaces spaces and hyphens with underscores.

You can use this function like so:

```julia
col = "My Column"
println(clean_column(col)) # Outputs: "my_column"
```
